prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 - WR 11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary goal of this observation is to get a solid continuum estimate for a WC+O binary, which when paired with continuum observations in Band 3, will provide measurement of the spectral index. Additionally, we will observe the spectral lines of CO 2-1, SiO, and H(30)-alpha (radio recombination line RRL) to probe the ionization structure and understand the gas kinematics. As the brightest target in the mm, we propose to obtain a SNR~10 for the RRL to quantify the ionization emission at these wavelengths for WR stars.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have tuned the correlator to optimize use of the base bands to observe the continuum for our primary goal of constraining the SED as well as observing spectral lines. A base band is situated at the frequencies of the RRL H(30)-alpha, which will allow us to determine ionization, and CO 2-1, to understand gas kinematics and constrain dust. The second base band then allows observations of the continuum at 215 GHz, as well as SiO (with which we will evaluate excitation from shocks and outflows).

Spatial resolution is key to identifying emission directly from the WR wind and/or dust , and thus omit contamination from the surrounding environment. At present, the best resolution of WR observations in the millimeter is 11" (Altenhoff et al. 1994) which corresponds to ~0.5 pc at a distance of 10 kpc. Fig. 3 clearly shows that previous observations with 11" beams or greater do not come close to constraining the WR emission, and that even 2" resolution observations previously attainable with CARMA would not resolve the most extended dust formation in WR winds. With a synthesized beam of ~0.3", these observations will resolve size scales <0.02 pc at the same distance, and will allow us to disentangle emission from the WR stars from their environment for the first time. The stars themselves are point sources, and thus adopting a largest angular scale of 0.5 arcsec is conservative.

The requested sensitivity for this observation is calculated based on the Hydrogen recombination line strengths, particularly for the case of this target WR 11. WR 11 is the brightest WR in the mm and therefore we expect it is the easiest to detect RRLs in the stellar wind with adequate sensitivity. We adopt a conservative RRL strength based on the line-to-continuum ratios (~0.05) observed in the stellar winds of stars by Altenhoff et al. 1981 and Thum et al. 2013. For comparison, RRL strengths estimated from brightness temperature ratios of line versus continuum from Hjellming et al. (1969) assuming a relatively low density environment in the wind region of n ~10^-2 cm^-3 and a temperature of 10^4 K suggest the brightness temperatures of the H(38)-alpha line to be greater or equal to that of the continuum. Extrapolations to H(30)-alpha suggest an even higher ratio. However the value of ~0.5 is the only detection to date in stellar winds, which we adopt to ensure that this Hydrogen recombination line is detected with enough sensitivity, which also ensures detection of the continuum. We extrapolate the continuum emission based on previous single dish detections at 1.1mm (Williams et al. 1987), assuming the predicted frequency dependency of nu^0.6 (as discussed in the text). We seek a detection of H(30)-alpha >10 signal-to-noise to obtain a well-characterized line profile; thus to obtain a rms sensitivity of 2 mJy with spectral bins of 1.263 km/s, results in a time on source of 25.70 min, resulting in a total estimated time of 52.53 min.
The emission from the CO 2-1 line is expected to be above this sensitivity limit. With the proposed observation, we will detect CO and thus enable studies of the gas kinematics and likely trace the dust. We estimate the CO line strengths using the only published values of CO observations of a WR star (not the large, surrounding ring nebula), which is WR 104 (McCall et al. 2002). NIR measurements of vibrationally excited CO 1-0 reveal a column density of ~1.e16 cm^-2 of warm CO (McCall et al. 2002). ALMA will detect the same amount of CO (as a lower limit) as well as additional cool CO. Models of the dust shell suggest an extent of approximately 5000 AU (Williams et al. 1990), which we adopt as the approximate volume that is filled. Using T=100-300K, the observed column density of N(CO)=1.e16cm-2, and a gas volume density of 1e-3 to 1e-4 cm-3 from the dust shell model, the RADEX non-LTE excitation code predicts optical depths in the CO 1-0 and 2-1 lines of 0.05-0.5, and brightness temperatures of 3-10K. The SiO line is only expected to be present along outflows and shocks - thus may be observed in the WR winds. SiO in WR winds are not known, and we have tuned the correlator to observe them if they are there, which we will detect if the line strength is >10 mJy.
WRs are known for their powerful winds, with terminal velocities of ~1000 km/s. We expect the WR continuum to have line widths over 500 km/s, and therefore do not require high spectral resolution and optimize signal with high bandwidth. We will integrate over 44 km/s bins in order to maximize the S/N. However, observations of H3+ and CO in WR104 (McCall et al. 2002) find line widths of 5-15 km/s, and thus we observe all spectral lines with 1.3 km/s bins. Because of the expected broad lines, we have checked the tunings to ensure that the lines we will observe are sufficiently spaced from the edge of the base bands such that the full line will be contained.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 - WR 11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary goal of this observation is to get a solid continuum estimate for a WC+O binary in Band 3. By multiple continuum measurements, we will be able to measure the spectral index of the WR star across Band 3 (mm wavelengths at which the star has not been previously observed, where the wind thermal wind is thought to dominate) and when paired with continuum observations in Band 6, will provide measurement of the broader spectral index. Additionally, we will observe the spectral line of CO 1-0 to pair with observations of CO 2-1 to identify the temperature and mass of the CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have tuned the correlator to enable continuum measurements at available frequencies across the band (which have not been observed in the literature) for our primary goal of constraining the SED as well as observing spectral lines. The upper base band is situated at the frequency of the CO 1-0 line, to understand gas kinematics and constrain dust if it is detectable.

Spatial resolution is key to identifying emission directly from the WR wind and/or dust , and thus omit contamination from the surrounding environment. At present, the best resolution of WR observations in the millimeter is 11" (Altenhoff et al. 1994) which corresponds to ~0.5 pc at a distance of 10 kpc. Fig. 3 clearly shows that previous observations with 11" beams or greater do not come close to constraining the WR emission, and that even 2" resolution observations previously attainable with CARMA would not resolve the most extended dust formation in WR winds. With a synthesized beam of ~0.3", these observations will resolve size scales <0.02 pc at the same distance, and will allow us to disentangle emission from the WR stars from their environment for the first time. The stars themselves are point sources, and thus adopting a largest angular scale of 0.5 arcsec is conservative.

The proposed observation is designed for the primary purpose of detecting the continuum; however we additionally may detect CO 1-0 and allow for this possibility. The requested sensitivity for this observation is calculated by extrapolating the observed continuum emission of previous single dish detections at 1.1mm (Williams et al. 1987), assuming the predicted frequency dependency of nu^0.6 (as discussed in the text). We seek a detection of the continuum with >100 signal-to-noise to obtain adequate sensitivities to constrain the shape of the SED; thus to obtain a rms sensitivity of 2.5 mJy with spectral bins of ~90 km/s, results in a time on source of 2.01 min, resulting in a total estimated time of 22.60 min.
The emission from the CO 1-0 line is expected to be at the sensitivity limit. With the proposed observation, we will detect CO and thus enable studies of the gas kinematics and likely trace the dust. We estimate the CO line strengths using the only published values of CO observations of a WR star (not the large, surrounding ring nebula), which is WR 104 (McCall et al. 2002). NIR measurements of vibrationally excited CO 1-0 reveal a column density of ~1.e16 cm^-2 of warm CO (McCall et al. 2002). ALMA will detect the same amount of CO (as a lower limit) as well as additional cool CO. Models of the dust shell suggest an extent of approximately 5000 AU (Williams et al. 1990), which we adopt as the approximate volume that is filled. Using T=100-300K, the observed column density of N(CO)=1.e16cm-2, and a gas volume density of 1e-3 to 1e-4 cm-3 from the dust shell model, the RADEX non-LTE excitation code predicts optical depths in the CO 1-0 and 2-1 lines of 0.05-0.5, and brightness temperatures of 3-10K. Thus ,we may detect the CO 1-0 line, especially if it is stronger than expected.
WRs are known for their powerful winds, with terminal velocities of ~1000 km/s. We expect the WR continuum to have line widths over 500 km/s, and therefore do not require high spectral resolution and optimize signal with high bandwidth. We will integrate over 90 km/s bins in order to maximize the S/N. However, observations of H3+ and CO in WR104 (McCall et al. 2002) find line widths of 5-15 km/s, and thus we observe all spectral lines with 1.3 km/s bins. Because of the expected broad lines, we have checked the tunings to ensure that the lines we will observe are sufficiently spaced from the edge of the base bands such that the full line will be contained.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 - WR 90
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary goal of this observation is to get a solid continuum estimate for a single WC star, which when paired with continuum observations in Band 3, will provide measurement of the spectral index. Additionally, we will observe the spectral lines of CO 2-1, SiO, and H(30)-alpha (radio recombination line RRL) to probe the ionization structure and understand the gas kinematics.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have tuned the correlator to optimize base bands to observe the continuum for our primary goal of constraining the SED as well as observing spectral lines. A base band is situated at the frequencies of the RRL H(30)-alpha, which will allow us to determine ionization, and CO 2-1, to understand gas kinematics and constrain dust. The second base band then allows observations of the continuum at 215 GHz, as well as SiO (with which we will evaluate excitation from shocks and outflows). We use a spectral averaging of 2 for the lines to lower the data rate.

Spatial resolution is key to identifying emission directly from the WR wind and/or dust , and thus omit contamination from the surrounding environment. At present, the best resolution of WR observations in the millimeter is 11" (Altenhoff et al. 1994) which corresponds to ~0.5 pc at a distance of 10 kpc. Fig. 3 clearly shows that previous observations with 11" beams or greater do not come close to constraining the WR emission, and that even 2" resolution observations previously attainable with CARMA would not resolve the most extended dust formation in WR winds. With a synthesized beam of ~0.3", these observations will resolve size scales <0.02 pc at the same distance, and will allow us to disentangle emission from the WR stars from their environment for the first time. The stars themselves are point sources, and thus adopting a largest angular scale of 0.5 arcsec is conservative.

The proposed observation is designed for the primary purpose of detecting the continuum; however we additionally will likely detect CO 2-1 and allow for the possibility of detecting SiO and an RRL. The requested sensitivity for this observation is calculated by extrapolating the observed continuum emission of previous single dish detections at 1.3mm (Setia Gunawan et al. 2001), assuming the predicted frequency dependency of nu^0.6 (as discussed in the text). The RRL strength may be at or below the sensitivity to adequately detect the continuum. We adopt a conservative RRL strength based on the line-to-continuum ratios (~0.05) observed in the stellar winds of stars by Altenhoff et al. 1981 and Thum et al. 2013. For comparison, RRL strengths estimated from brightness temperature ratios of line versus continuum from Hjellming et al. (1969) assuming a relatively low density environment in the wind region of n ~10^-2 cm^-3 and a temperature of 10^4 K suggest the brightness temperatures of the H(38)-alpha line to be greater or equal to that of the continuum. Extrapolations to H(30)-alpha suggest an even higher ratio. However the value of ~0.05 is the only detection to date in stellar winds and will not be detected with low sensitivity, however note that the RRL may be observed with a higher line-to-continuum ratio. As such, we request to detect obtain a signal-to-noise ratio of 50, the same as proposed for the continuum in Band 3, to obtain adequate sensitivities to constrain the shape of the SED; thus to obtain a rms sensitivity of 0.4 mJy with spectral bins of ~43 km/s, results in a time on source of 24.19 min, resulting in a total estimated time of 50.94 min.
The emission from the CO 2-1 line is expected to be above this sensitivity limit. With the proposed observation, we will detect CO and thus enable studies of the gas kinematics and likely trace the dust. We estimate the CO line strengths using the only published values of CO observations of a WR star (not the large, surrounding ring nebula), which is WR 104 (McCall et al. 2002). NIR measurements of vibrationally excited CO 1-0 reveal a column density of ~1.e16 cm^-2 of warm CO (McCall et al. 2002). ALMA will detect the same amount of CO (as a lower limit) as well as additional cool CO. Models of the dust shell suggest an extent of approximately 5000 AU (Williams et al. 1990), which we adopt as the approximate volume that is filled. Using T=100-300K, the observed column density of N(CO)=1.e16cm-2, and a gas volume density of 1e-3 to 1e-4 cm-3 from the dust shell model, the RADEX non-LTE excitation code predicts optical depths in the CO 1-0 and 2-1 lines of 0.05-0.5, and brightness temperatures of 3-10K. The SiO line is only expected to be present along outflows and shocks - thus may be observed in the WR winds. SiO in WR winds are not known, and we have tuned the correlator to observe them if they are there, which we will detect if the line strength is >0.4 mJy.
WRs are known for their powerful winds, with terminal velocities of ~1000 km/s. We expect the WR continuum to have line widths over 500 km/s, and therefore do not require high spectral resolution and optimize signal with high bandwidth. We will integrate over 44 km/s bins in order to maximize the S/N. However, observations of H3+ and CO in WR104 (McCall et al. 2002) find line widths of 5-15 km/s, and thus we observe all spectral lines with 1.3 km/s bins. Because of the expected broad lines, we have checked the tunings to ensure that the lines we will observe are sufficiently spaced from the edge of the base bands such that the full line will be contained.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary goal of this observation is to get a solid continuum estimate for a single WC star in Band 3. By multiple continuum measurements, we will be able to measure the spectral index of the WR star across Band 3 (mm wavelengths at which the star has not been previously observed, where the wind thermal wind is thought to dominate) and when paired with continuum observations in Band 6, will provide measurement of the broader spectral index. Additionally, we will observe the spectral line of CO 1-0 to pair with observations of CO 2-1 to identify the temperature and mass of the CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have tuned the correlator to enable continuum measurements at available frequencies across the band (which have not been observed in the literature) for our primary goal of constraining the SED as well as observing spectral lines. The upper base band is situated at the frequency of the CO 1-0 line, to understand gas kinematics and constrain dust if it is detectable.

Spatial resolution is key to identifying emission directly from the WR wind and/or dust , and thus omit contamination from the surrounding environment. At present, the best resolution of WR observations in the millimeter is 11" (Altenhoff et al. 1994) which corresponds to ~0.5 pc at a distance of 10 kpc. Fig. 3 clearly shows that previous observations with 11" beams or greater do not come close to constraining the WR emission, and that even 2" resolution observations previously attainable with CARMA would not resolve the most extended dust formation in WR winds. With a synthesized beam of ~0.3", these observations will resolve size scales <0.02 pc at the same distance, and will allow us to disentangle emission from the WR stars from their environment for the first time. The stars themselves are point sources, and thus adopting a largest angular scale of 0.5 arcsec is conservative.

The proposed observation is designed for the primary purpose of detecting the continuum; however we additionally may detect CO 1-0 and allow for this possibility. The requested sensitivity for this observation is calculated by extrapolating the observed continuum emission of previous single dish detections at 1.3mm (Setia Gunawan et al. 2001), assuming the predicted frequency dependency of nu^0.6 (as discussed in the text). We seek a detection of the continuum with >50 signal-to-noise to obtain adequate sensitivities to constrain the shape of the SED; thus to obtain a rms sensitivity of 0.25 mJy with spectral bins of ~90 km/s, results in a time on source of 1.06hr, resulting in a total estimated time of 1.98hr.
The emission from the CO 1-0 line is expected to be at this sensitivity limit. With the proposed observation, we will detect CO and thus enable studies of the gas kinematics and likely trace the dust. We estimate the CO line strengths using the only published values of CO observations of a WR star (not the large, surrounding ring nebula), which is WR 104 (McCall et al. 2002). NIR measurements of vibrationally excited CO 1-0 reveal a column density of ~1.e16 cm^-2 of warm CO (McCall et al. 2002). ALMA will detect the same amount of CO (as a lower limit) as well as additional cool CO. Models of the dust shell suggest an extent of approximately 5000 AU (Williams et al. 1990), which we adopt as the approximate volume that is filled. Using T=100-300K, the observed column density of N(CO)=1.e16cm-2, and a gas volume density of 1e-3 to 1e-4 cm-3 from the dust shell model, the RADEX non-LTE excitation code predicts optical depths in the CO 1-0 and 2-1 lines of 0.05-0.5, and brightness temperatures of 3-10K. Thus ,we may detect the CO 1-0 line, especially if it is stronger than expected.
WRs are known for their powerful winds, with terminal velocities of ~1000 km/s. We expect the WR continuum to have line widths over 500 km/s, and therefore do not require high spectral resolution and optimize signal with high bandwidth. We will integrate over 90 km/s bins in order to maximize the S/N. However, observations of H3+ and CO in WR104 (McCall et al. 2002) find line widths of 5-15 km/s, and thus we observe all spectral lines with 1.3 km/s bins. Because of the expected broad lines, we have checked the tunings to ensure that the lines we will observe are sufficiently spaced from the edge of the base bands such that the full line will be contained.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 - WR 65
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary goal of this observation is to get a solid continuum estimate for a dusty WC+O binary, which when paired with continuum observations in Band 3, will provide measurement of the spectral index. Additionally, we will observe the spectral lines of CO 2-1, SiO, and H(30)-alpha (radio recombination line RRL) to probe the ionization structure and understand the gas kinematics.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have tuned the correlator to optimize base bands to observe the continuum for our primary goal of constraining the SED as well as observing spectral lines. A base band is situated at the frequencies of the RRL H(30)-alpha, which will allow us to determine ionization, and CO 2-1, to understand gas kinematics and constrain dust. The second base band then allows observations of the continuum at 215 GHz, as well as SiO (with which we will evaluate excitation from shocks and outflows). We use a spectral averaging of 2 for the lines to lower the data rate.

Spatial resolution is key to identifying emission directly from the WR wind and/or dust , and thus omit contamination from the surrounding environment. At present, the best resolution of WR observations in the millimeter is 11" (Altenhoff et al. 1994) which corresponds to ~0.5 pc at a distance of 10 kpc. Fig. 3 clearly shows that previous observations with 11" beams or greater do not come close to constraining the WR emission, and that even 2" resolution observations previously attainable with CARMA would not resolve the most extended dust formation in WR winds. With a synthesized beam of ~0.3", these observations will resolve size scales <0.02 pc at the same distance, and will allow us to disentangle emission from the WR stars from their environment for the first time. The stars themselves are point sources, and thus adopting a largest angular scale of 0.5 arcsec is conservative.

The proposed observation is designed for the primary purpose of detecting the continuum; however we additionally will likely detect CO 2-1 and allow for the possibility of detecting SiO and an RRL. The requested sensitivity for this observation is calculated by extrapolating the observed continuum emission of previous single dish detections at 1.3mm (Setia Gunawan et al. 2001), assuming the predicted frequency dependency of nu^0.6 (as discussed in the text). The RRL strength may be at or below the sensitivity to adequately detect the continuum. We adopt a conservative RRL strength based on the line-to-continuum ratios (~0.05) observed in the stellar winds of stars by Altenhoff et al. 1981 and Thum et al. 2013. For comparison, RRL strengths estimated from brightness temperature ratios of line versus continuum from Hjellming et al. (1969) assuming a relatively low density environment in the wind region of n ~10^-2 cm^-3 and a temperature of 10^4 K suggest the brightness temperatures of the H(38)-alpha line to be greater or equal to that of the continuum. However the value of ~0.05 is the only detection to date in stellar winds and will not be detected with low sensitivity, however note that the RRL may be observed with a higher line-to-continuum ratio. As such, we request to detect obtain a signal-to-noise ratio of 50, the same as the proposed continuum in Band 3, to constrain the shape of the SED; thus to obtain a rms sensitivity of 0.5 mJy with spectral bins of ~43 km/s, results in a time on source of 17.13 min, resulting in a total estimated time of 41.93 min.
The emission from the CO 2-1 line is expected to be above this sensitivity limit. With the proposed observation, we will detect CO and thus enable studies of the gas kinematics and likely trace the dust. We estimate the CO line strengths using the only published values of CO observations of a WR star (not the large, surrounding ring nebula), which is WR 104 (McCall et al. 2002). NIR measurements of vibrationally excited CO 1-0 reveal a column density of ~1.e16 cm^-2 of warm CO (McCall et al. 2002). ALMA will detect the same amount of CO (as a lower limit) as well as additional cool CO. Models of the dust shell suggest an extent of approximately 5000 AU (Williams et al. 1990), which we adopt as the approximate volume that is filled. Using T=100-300K, the observed column density of N(CO)=1.e16cm-2, and a gas volume density of 1e-3 to 1e-4 cm-3 from the dust shell model, the RADEX non-LTE excitation code predicts optical depths in the CO 1-0 and 2-1 lines of 0.05-0.5, and brightness temperatures of 3-10K. The SiO line is only expected to be present along outflows and shocks - thus may be observed in the WR winds. SiO in WR winds are not known, and we have tuned the correlator to observe them if they are there, which we will detect if the line strength is >0.5 mJy.
WRs are known for their powerful winds, with terminal velocities of ~1000 km/s. We expect the WR continuum to have line widths over 500 km/s, and therefore do not require high spectral resolution and optimize signal with high bandwidth. We will integrate over 44 km/s bins in order to maximize the S/N. However, observations of H3+ and CO in WR104 (McCall et al. 2002) find line widths of 5-15 km/s, and thus we observe all spectral lines with 1.3 km/s bins. Because of the expected broad lines, we have checked the tunings to ensure that the lines we will observe are sufficiently spaced from the edge of the base bands such that the full line will be contained.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 - WR 65
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary goal of this observation is to get a solid continuum estimate for a dusty WC+O binary in Band 3. By multiple continuum measurements, we will be able to measure the spectral index of the WR star across Band 3 (mm wavelengths at which the star has not been previously observed, where the wind thermal wind is thought to dominate)and when paired with continuum observations in Band 6, will provide measurement of the broader spectral index. Additionally, we will observe the spectral line of CO 1-0 to pair with observations of CO 2-1 to identify the temperature and mass of the CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have tuned the correlator to enable continuum measurements at available frequencies across the band (which have not been observed in the literature) for our primary goal of constraining the SED as well as observing spectral lines. The upper base band is situated at the frequency of the CO 1-0 line, to understand gas kinematics and constrain dust if it is detectable.

Spatial resolution is key to identifying emission directly from the WR wind and/or dust , and thus omit contamination from the surrounding environment. At present, the best resolution of WR observations in the millimeter is 11" (Altenhoff et al. 1994) which corresponds to ~0.5 pc at a distance of 10 kpc. Fig. 3 clearly shows that previous observations with 11" beams or greater do not come close to constraining the WR emission, and that even 2" resolution observations previously attainable with CARMA would not resolve the most extended dust formation in WR winds. With a synthesized beam of ~0.3", these observations will resolve size scales <0.02 pc at the same distance, and will allow us to disentangle emission from the WR stars from their environment for the first time. The stars themselves are point sources, and thus adopting a largest angular scale of 0.5 arcsec is conservative. NIR measurements resolve the WR dust shells to be 10-100 mas (e.g. Monnier et al. 2007), and ALMA will likely be able to resolve the dust shell around this dusty WR target.

The proposed observation is designed for the primary purpose of detecting the continuum; however we additionally may detect CO 1-0 and allow for this possibility. The requested sensitivity for this observation is calculated by extrapolating the observed continuum emission of previous single dish detections at 1.3mm (Setia Gunawan et al. 2001), assuming the predicted frequency dependency of nu^0.6 (as discussed in the text). We seek a detection of the continuum with >50 signal-to-noise to obtain adequate sensitivities to constrain the shape of the SED; thus to obtain a rms sensitivity of 0.34 mJy with spectral bins of ~90 km/s, results in a time on source of 31.25 min, resulting in a total estimated time of 59.01 min.
The emission from the CO 1-0 line is expected to be at this sensitivity limit. With the proposed observation, we will detect CO and thus enable studies of the gas kinematics and likely trace the dust. We estimate the CO line strengths using the only published values of CO observations of a WR star (not the large, surrounding ring nebula), which is WR 104 (McCall et al. 2002). NIR measurements of vibrationally excited CO 1-0 reveal a column density of ~1.e16 cm^-2 of warm CO (McCall et al. 2002). ALMA will detect the same amount of CO (as a lower limit) as well as additional cool CO. Models of the dust shell suggest an extent of approximately 5000 AU (Williams et al. 1990), which we adopt as the approximate volume that is filled. Using T=100-300K, the observed column density of N(CO)=1.e16cm-2, and a gas volume density of 1e-3 to 1e-4 cm-3 from the dust shell model, the RADEX non-LTE excitation code predicts optical depths in the CO 1-0 and 2-1 lines of 0.05-0.5, and brightness temperatures of 3-10K. Thus ,we may detect the CO 1-0 line, especially if it is stronger than expected.
WRs are known for their powerful winds, with terminal velocities of ~1000 km/s. We expect the WR continuum to have line widths over 500 km/s, and therefore do not require high spectral resolution and optimize signal with high bandwidth. We will integrate over 90 km/s bins in order to maximize the S/N. However, observations of H3+ and CO in WR104 (McCall et al. 2002) find line widths of 5-15 km/s, and thus we observe all spectral lines with 1.3 km/s bins. Because of the expected broad lines, we have checked the tunings to ensure that the lines we will observe are sufficiently spaced from the edge of the base bands such that the full line will be contained.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a pilot study to observe the (sub)mm emission from Wolf-Rayet stars with ALMA to constrain the shape of the spectral energy distribution in the mm regime, which will provide substantial insight that is necessary for interpreting regions hosting WRs. Limited previous mm studies have had beam sizes of >11", and with ALMA's ~0.35" beam, we will be able to resolve Wolf-Rayet emission and disentangle it from its environment for the first time. This proposed study using Band 3 and Band 6 continuum observations and spectral line diagnostics (such as CO, SiO, and H(30)-alpha) will provide a new window into the powerful Wolf-Rayet winds and leverage different WR types to identify contributions to the mm emission. In addition, we will investigate (and possibly resolve!) the formation and survival of dust in extreme environment of the WRs.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Virginia, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Virginia, University of
